bibl.title: >Letter from Henry Rose Carter to E.C. Houle, April 18, 1923

div1.p: Carter requests information on the traffic from the western coasts of Central and South America to Australia.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to E.C. Houle, April 18, 1923
div1.opener:
Similar letters to:
1/ Surgeon R. H. Creel, Angel Island, San Francisco, Cal
2/ Surgeon Wm. C. Rucker, C. Z.
3/ A. A. Surgeon Carlos V. Coello, Guayaquil, Ecuador
4/ A. A. Surgeon J. L. Castro-Guiterrez, Callao, Peru.
/LC
I. H B.
Australia
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
April 18, 1923.
Dr. E. C. Houle,
Chief Surgeon F. C. S. P. de M.,
Empalme, Sonora, Mexico.
Dear Doctor Houle:
div1.p:
I am asked to write an article for the Australian health au-
thorities, setting forth the dangers of the introduction of yellow
fever from the West Coast of America into that country, directly or
via the south-east of Asia. In my mind there is none at present
and should be less than none if possible in the future.

Can you give me any data you have, or can get, on the traffic
from the West Coast to eastern Asia? There is, I think, a Japanese
line from Peruvian: Guayaquil and Mexican ports going across.

I would like to have all the data possible on this subject:
The number of trips per annum: the itinerary: the schedule--i. e.
length of time en route: tonnage of vessels and nature of traffic--
whether exclusively freight or passenger and freight.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W, Washington, D. C.
